title: Filing judgment lien with county recorder: How to ensure lien is filed against correct person's property?
question: I won a large judgment in a small claims case and will be filing an abstract of judgment with the county recorder's office. I have received the abstract from the court and now need to file it. The judgment debtor has a common name. How do I ensure that:
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Judgment lien,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Social security,Small claims court
answers: I agree with the previous counsel. Good luck!

I agree with my colleagues: The lien will be indexed by the judgment debtor's name rather than by his properties. The last 4 digits of his SSN will pin down which John Smith's properties have been encumbered by the liens.

At minimum, you should record one AOJ per county in which the debtor owns any real property. The lien will attach to multiple properties owned or subsequently acquired in that county. You may also record AOJ's in as many counties as you wish; e.g., if the judgment debtor resides in So Cal, some collections attorneys will record AOJs in all the Southern California counties just to make sure any future purchases in those counties will immediately be encumbered by the creditor's lien. The financial worthiness of recording in multiple counties largely depends upon the size of the judgment and the likelihood the debtor has resources to purchase real property.

The recorder does not match your lien up with the property. When you record the lien, it automatically attaches to the judgment debtor's property. A potential buyer or lender of any property that he owns would check to see whether he has granted any interest in the property since acquiring it. Your judgment lien would show up. Before it was all computerized, we would say that it showed up in the grantor index.

The real question is what about all the other John Smiths who own property in the county and must show that your lien does not affect them.

When you record an Abstract of Judgment in each county, it places a judgment lien on any real property owns or MAY own in the future within that county. You are not recording a lien against any particular property.

It is not necessary to include the letter to the county recorder. So long as you include the last known address on the abstract of judgment, a title company or anyone else searching public records will be able to ascertain whether or not it is the same John Smith against whom you have a judgment.
